oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb -- The newly built boys' dormitory, Cottage D

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Construction; Dormitories; Buildings
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Knoxville (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The boys' dormitory, Cottage D, at the Tennessee School for the Deaf with construction drawing to a close. Windows, doors, and front entry steps have all been added within the course of a month's construction, and no construction equipment is present in this image. Writing on the reverse side of the photograph includes details about furnishings in the dormitory.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr & Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1922, 125 acres in south Knoxville (the Dickinson estate in Island Home Park) was acquired to be the new home of the Tennessee School for the Deaf. Marr & Holman, a prominent Nashville architectural firm, was hired to design the new campus buildings.; (Thomas S. Marr had attended the Tennessee School for the Deaf from 1877 to 1884.) In 1926 this dormitory building was added. The contractor was V. L. Nicholson. Other structures would follow and expand the campus.
